p: Trichinella spiralis is acquired through the ingestion of contaminated raw pork. The larvae may be found in the liver and gallbladder. The clinical manifestations include diarrhea fever, marked eosinophilia, and obstructive jaundice. Diagnosis is suggested by the characteristic history and serological analysis. A muscle biopsy may help confirm the diagnosis. Treatment is with anti-helminthics such as albendazole or mebendazole [ 57, 58].
